051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.010915ae-1abc-4c36-9cff-0f1693e7518a.description=This operation runs a SQL command. Inputs\: DBServerName - The hostname or ip address of the database server. DbType - The type of database to connect to. Valid values\: Oracle, MSSQL, Sybase, Netcool, DB2 and Custom. Default value\: Oracle Username - The username to use when connecting to the database. Password - The password to use when connecting to the database. instance - The name instance (for MSSQL Server). Leave it blank for default instance. DbPort - The port to connect to. Default values\: Oracle\: 1521, MSSQL\: 1433, Sybase\: 5000, Netcool\: 4100, DB2\: 50000. Database - The name of the database. authenticationType - The type of authentication used to access the database (applicable only to MSSQL type). Valid values\: sql, windows (for MSSQL) Default value\: sql dbClass - The classname of the JDBC driver to use. dbURL - The url required to load up the driver and make your connection. Command - The command to execute. timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution. When the default value is used, there is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running command to complete. Default value\: 0 databasePoolingProperties - Properties for database pooling configuration. This parameter replaces the databasePooling.properties file from 9x version (you may copy-paste the file content here). Pooling is disabled by default. For more details check the /Library/Operations/Database/JDBC folder description. Example\: db.pooling.enable\=true resultSetType - the result set type. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY, TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,TYPE_SCROLL_SENSITIVE. Default value\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY resultSetConcurrency - the result set concurrency. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY, CONCUR_UPDATABLE Default value\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY Results\: returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "Command completed successfully" message if the operation succeeded, or a failure message otherwise. outputText - The return result of SQL command. updateCount - The update count of the command executed. Responses\: success - The command was executed successfully. failure - Failed to execute the command. Note\: 1. Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 2. In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.0209db5c-13d4-458b-aee5-04592141797f.description=
This operation does not do anything. It can be used to filter flow variables by defining them as inputs and filtering them in the Results tab.

Inputs\:
    field1 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field2 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field3 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
    field4 – An optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Results\:
    returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the value of  "field1" as it was specified at input or when filtered. 

Responses\:
    success - The operation completed as stated in the description.

In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.284604ed-7871-4561-9933-d6a7772a5c62.description=
This operation is used to send a smtp email.
 
Inputs\:
    hostname - The hostname or ip address of the smtp server.
    port - The port smtp service is listening.
    from - From email address.
    to - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients.
    cc - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients, to be placed in the CC.
    bcc - A delimiter separated list of email address(es) or recipients, to be placed in the BCC.
    subject - The email subject. If a subject spans on multiple lines, it is formatted to a single one.
    body - The body of the email.
    htmlEmail - The value should be true if the email is in rich text/html format. The value should be false if the email is in plain text format.
Valid values\: true, false. 
Default value\: true. 
    readReceipt - The value should be true if read receipt is required, else false. 
Valid values\: true, false. 
Default value\: false. 
    attachments - A delimiter separated list of files to attach (must be full path).
    headers - This input contains extra headers you want to be added in the mail. The input has a 'Map' format. Header names are separated from header values through a column delimiter and headers will be separated between them by a row delimiter.
Example\:
    Sensitivity\:Company-Confidential
    message-type\:Multiple Part
    Sensitivity\:Personal
In the above example, the columnDelimiter is "\:" and the rowDelimiter is the new line. You can define multiple values for the same header like in the example above. The delimiters can have multiple characters, but be careful that the rowDelimiter is not a substring of the columnDelimiter.
    rowDelimiter - The delimiter that separates headers in the 'headers' input.
Default value\: "\:"
Examples\: '|', '\='
    columnDelimiter - The delimiter that separates the header name from header value on the same row.
Default value\: "\n"	
Examples\: ';', '\#'
    username - If SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send.
    password - If SMTP authentication is needed, the password to use.
    characterSet - The character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. 
Valid values\: UTF-8, UTF-16, UTF-32, EUC-JP, ISO-2022-JP, Shift_JIS, Windows-31J.
Default value\: UTF-8.
    contentTransferEncoding - The content transfer encoding scheme (such as 7bit, 8bit, base64, quoted-printable etc) for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. 
Valid values\: quoted-printable, base64, 7bit, 8bit, binary, x-token.
Default value\: quoted-printable (or Q Encoding).
    delimiter - A delimiter to separate the email recipients and the attachments.
Default value\: ','
    encryptionKeystore - The path to the pks12 formatted keystore used to encrypt the mail.
    encryptionKeyAlias - The alias of a RSA key pair from the encryptionKeystore. The public key from the pair will be used to encrypt the mail. The key pair must not have password. The recommended key size is 2048 bit or higher.
    encryptionKeystorePassword - The password for the encryptionKeystore.
    encryptionAlgorithm - The encryption algorithm applied on the key from the keystore in order to encypt email parts. 
Default value\: AES256_CBC.
Valid values\: DES_EDE3_CBC, RC2_CBC, IDEA_CBC, CAST5_CBC, AES128_CBC, AES192_CBC, AES256_CBC, CAMELLIA128_CBC, CAMELLIA192_CBC, CAMELLIA256_CBC, SEED_CBC, DES_EDE3_WRAP, AES128_WRAP, AES256_WRAP, CAMELLIA128_WRAP, CAMELLIA192_WRAP, CAMELLIA256_WRAP, SEED_WRAP.
    enableTLS - Enables starttls. If the server supports TLS or SSL, the communications will be secured by TLS or SSL. If it doesn't support TLS or SSL the communication will be unsecure.
Valid values\: true, false. 
Default value\: false.
    timeout - The timeout in seconds for sending the mail message.

Responses\:
    success - Successfully sent the email.
    failure - Failed to send the email.

Note\:
1. For special characters (East Asian, right-to-left languages, etc.) you must install the support files on your local machine.
2. For doing this on Windows go to Control Panel -> Regional and Language Options -> Language and check the options at Supplemental language support.
3. You can use KeyStore Explorer to obtain RSA Keystore with keyPairs for encryption/decryption.
    3.1 If you get "llegal key size exception" you don't have JCE Unlimited Strength installed.

Compares two strings, returning a true response if and only if they contain the same sequence of characters. A null string is considered to be equal to an empty string.

Inputs\:
    string1 - The first string. 
Default value\: "" (empty)
    string2 - The second string.
Default value\: "" (empty)
    ignoreCase - If set to 'true', then the comparison ignores case considerations. The two strings are considered equal ignoring case if they are of the same length and corresponding characters in the two strings are equal ignoring case. If set to any value other than 'true', then the strings must match exactly to be considered equal.

Responses\:
    true - If the two strings are equal.
    false - If the two strings are not equal.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.35b1a3fc-6170-4561-ae07-11db433d0756.description=
This operation sends email via SMTP.      

Inputs\:
SMTPServer - The hostname or ip address of the smtp server.
MailType - The format of the message body. Valid values are\: html, text.
Attachments - A comma separated list of files to attach to the mail (Example\: c\:\test.txt,c\:\excel.xls).
From - SMTP address of the sender (Example\: sender@domain.com).
To - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of whom the email should be sent to (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com).
Cc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Bcc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a blind carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Subject - The subject of the message.
Body - The body of the message.
username - If SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send (Example\: username).
password - The password to use.
port - The port smtp service is listening on.
characterSet - The character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. The values can be UTF-8, Shift_JIS, EUC-JP or ISO-2022-JP. Default value is UTF-8. 
contentTransferEncoding - Content transfer encoding scheme for the attachment. Supported encoding schemes are base64, quoted-printable and 7bit. Default value is quoted-printable. 7bit is supported only by ISO-2022-JP character set encoding. The operation will fail if 7bit is used with any other character set encoding.

Responses\:
success - Successfully sent the message.
failure - Failed to send message. See returnResult for more information.

Note\:
If SMTP authentication is not needed, then the operation will succeed even if invalid credentials are assigned to the username and password inputs.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.35d41647-4dde-473a-b470-266b9349105f.callout=Exception Process 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.37941c6c-c1a1-4abc-94e8-00cf78eb5627.description=
If the input dateFormat is not specified, it converts a date in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale, to a date either in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's or in the format specified in the input outFormat. 

If the input dateFormat is specified, it converts a date in the format in dateFormat to a date either in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's or in the format specified in the input outFormat.

You can use flow "Get Current Date and Time" to check upon the default date/time format.  

For exmaple, if OO Central Server's locale is English, the input dateFormat is empty and the input outFormat is empty, the input date should be in the format of "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the user specifies dateFormat as "dd-MM-YYYY HH\:mm\:ss", the input date should be in the format of "13-07-2006 10\:04\:08". If the input outFormat is empty, the result will be "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the input outFormat is "yyyy-MM-dd", the result will be "2006-07-13". The dateFormat for "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:078 AM" is "MMM dd, yyyy HH\:mm\:ss a". 


Specify the date format with the following patterns\:

Letter 	Date or Time Component 	Presentation 	Examples
G 	Era designator 	Text 	                     AD
y 	Year 	                     Year 	                     1996; 96
M 	Month in year 	Month 	                     July; Jul; 07
w 	Week in year 	Number 	                     27
W 	Week in month 	Number 	                     2
D 	Day in year 	                     Number 	                     189
d 	Day in month 	Number 	                     10
F 	Day of week in month 	Number 	                     2
E 	Day in week   	Text 	                     Tuesday; Tue
a 	Am/pm marker 	Text 	                     PM
H 	Hour in day (0-23) 	Number 	                     0
k 	Hour in day (1-24) 	Number 	                     24
K 	Hour in am/pm (0-11) 	Number 	                     0
h 	Hour in am/pm (1-12) 	Number 	                     12
m 	Minute in hour 	Number 	                     30
s 	Second in minute 	Number 	                     55
S 	Millisecond 	                     Number 	                     978
z 	Time zone 	                     General time zone 	Pacific Standard Time; PST; GMT-08\:00
Z 	Time zone 	                     RFC 822 time zone 	-0800

So, for example\: the date "2006-07-10 15\:16\:14.766 PDT" would have the dateFormat "yyyy-MM-dd HH\:mm\:ss.SSS z".

You can also use single quotes (') to avoid text interpretation. The quoted text will simply be copied into the output string during formatting (if present in the outFormat) or matched against the input string during parsing (if present in the dateFormat). For example, the date value "2006-07-10T15\:16\:14.766Z" would have the dateFormat "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSS'Z'". 


Inputs\:
date - The date to parse. If the input dateFormat is empty, the date must be in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale. If the input dateFormat is not empty, the date must be in the format specified in the input dateFormat.
dateFormat - The format of the input date. 
dateLocaleLang - The locale language for input dateFormat string. For example,  en or ja.  It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty. 
dateLocaleCountry - The locale country for input dateFormat string. For example, US or JP.  It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty or dateLocaleLang is empty. 
outFormat - The format of the output date/time. If it is empty, the output date/time will be in the format of date/time of OO Cental Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale.
outLocaleLang - The locale language for output string. For example,  en or ja. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty. 
outLocaleCountry - The locale country for output string. For example, US or JP. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty or outLocaleLang is empty.

Responses\:
success - The date was converted.
failure - The date could not be converted.

Result\:
The date in the new format.
The date in the new format.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.382a06b9-f8bc-4a42-8fe0-d0d27244cb03.description=
This operation sends email via SMTP.      

Inputs\:
SMTPServer - The hostname or ip address of the smtp server.
MailType - The format of the message body. Valid values are\: html, text.
Attachments - A comma separated list of files to attach to the mail (Example\: c\:\test.txt,c\:\excel.xls).
From - SMTP address of the sender (Example\: sender@domain.com).
To - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of whom the email should be sent to (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com).
Cc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Bcc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a blind carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Subject - The subject of the message.
Body - The body of the message.
username - If SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send (Example\: username).
password - The password to use.
port - The port smtp service is listening on.
characterSet - The character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. The values can be UTF-8, Shift_JIS, EUC-JP or ISO-2022-JP. Default value is UTF-8. 
contentTransferEncoding - Content transfer encoding scheme for the attachment. Supported encoding schemes are base64, quoted-printable and 7bit. Default value is quoted-printable. 7bit is supported only by ISO-2022-JP character set encoding. The operation will fail if 7bit is used with any other character set encoding.

Responses\:
success - Successfully sent the message.
failure - Failed to send message. See returnResult for more information.

Note\:

051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.390f5975-9759-4a1c-9637-dbd429e277f4.description=
Adds flow variables into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyNames - the names of the flow variables to use
myValues - the values to assign the flow variables
delimiter - a delimiter separating values and keys.

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];

051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.4425400d-dbf8-4cfb-902e-08c1e23fd1f4.callout=Apply Patches 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.46f442e4-acd2-4265-acb9-59860c67a9b3.callout=Check Change Ticket 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.47fe09c6-e303-477d-9578-84eb21e00ce5.description=
Writes the data from "contents" input to the requested file. The operation can be used to overwrite existing content of the file,  append extra lines to it or even create a new file.

Input Parameters\:
file                - Full path to file (can be a UNC path, will attempt to create directory structure). If the file does not exist it is created first.
contents        - The contents to write to the file. Contents can have a new line delimiter which is also given as input to the operation, but it is optional. Example\: "This is line no. 01\nThis is line no. 2\n" where \n is the delimiter.
user              - Username to use for thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation.
password      - Password for the user.
delimiter       - Specifies the newline delimiter (\n, \r\n, etc) that is used for the "contents" input.
overwrite      - Specifies whether to overwrite the file or append to it. By default, the used value is true. Accepted values\: true, false or the empty string. If this is left empty, the file will be overwritten.
characterSet - The character encoding used to write to the file. The default is UTF-8. Example values\: windows-1252, UTF-16, UTF-16BE,  ISO-8859-1, US-ASCII, Shift_JIS etc.

Responses\:
success - The contents were written to the file.
failure - The operation did not succeed in writing the contents to file.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.4b72c4d0-72cc-4de7-aa80-7f99db5e8b92.description=
Compares two dates. If the locale is not specified, the inputs must be in the format of date/time format of OO Central Server's, which is dependant of Java Locale. You can use flow " Get Current Date and Time" to check upon the default date/time format. If locale is specified, the inputs must be in the format of the locale. If locale is not specified, then default locale will be used.

Inputs\:
d1 - The first date. For example, if locale is not specified and the OS default locale is English, the format could be "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM" or "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM PST". If locale en is specified, the format should be "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM PST".
d2 - The second date.  It must be in the format that is the same as d1.
threshold -The number of milliseconds around each date that still allows the dates to be considered equal.
localeLang - The locale language for date and time string. For example,  en or ja.
localeCountry - The locale country for date and time string. For example, US or JP. If localeLang is not specified, this input will be ingored.

Responses\:
before - If d1 is before d2.
equal - If d1 is < d2 + threshold and d1 > d2-threshold.
after - If d1 is after d2.
failure - Something went wrong.

Returns\:
The value of d1-d2 in milliseconds.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.4de6b898-14d9-4984-9c02-d4b23fbc6e01.description=
If the input dateFormat is not specified, it converts a date in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale, to a date either in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's or in the format specified in the input outFormat. 

If the input dateFormat is specified, it converts a date in the format in dateFormat to a date either in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's or in the format specified in the input outFormat.

You can use flow "Get Current Date and Time" to check upon the default date/time format.  

For exmaple, if OO Central Server's locale is English, the input dateFormat is empty and the input outFormat is empty, the input date should be in the format of "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the user specifies dateFormat as "dd-MM-YYYY HH\:mm\:ss", the input date should be in the format of "13-07-2006 10\:04\:08". If the input outFormat is empty, the result will be "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:08 AM". If the input outFormat is "yyyy-MM-dd", the result will be "2006-07-13". The dateFormat for "July 13, 2006 10\:04\:078 AM" is "MMM dd, yyyy HH\:mm\:ss a". 


Specify the date format with the following patterns\:

Letter 	Date or Time Component 	Presentation 	Examples
G 	Era designator 	Text 	                     AD
y 	Year 	                     Year 	                     1996; 96
M 	Month in year 	Month 	                     July; Jul; 07
w 	Week in year 	Number 	                     27
W 	Week in month 	Number 	                     2
D 	Day in year 	                     Number 	                     189
d 	Day in month 	Number 	                     10
F 	Day of week in month 	Number 	                     2
E 	Day in week   	Text 	                     Tuesday; Tue
a 	Am/pm marker 	Text 	                     PM
H 	Hour in day (0-23) 	Number 	                     0
k 	Hour in day (1-24) 	Number 	                     24
K 	Hour in am/pm (0-11) 	Number 	                     0
h 	Hour in am/pm (1-12) 	Number 	                     12
m 	Minute in hour 	Number 	                     30
s 	Second in minute 	Number 	                     55
S 	Millisecond 	                     Number 	                     978
z 	Time zone 	                     General time zone 	Pacific Standard Time; PST; GMT-08\:00
Z 	Time zone 	                     RFC 822 time zone 	-0800

So, for example\: the date "2006-07-10 15\:16\:14.766 PDT" would have the dateFormat "yyyy-MM-dd HH\:mm\:ss.SSS z".

You can also use single quotes (') to avoid text interpretation. The quoted text will simply be copied into the output string during formatting (if present in the outFormat) or matched against the input string during parsing (if present in the dateFormat). For example, the date value "2006-07-10T15\:16\:14.766Z" would have the dateFormat "yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH\:mm\:ss.SSS'Z'". 


Inputs\:
date - The date to parse. If the input dateFormat is empty, the date must be in the format of date/time of OO Central Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale. If the input dateFormat is not empty, the date must be in the format specified in the input dateFormat.
dateFormat - The format of the input date. 
dateLocaleLang - The locale language for input dateFormat string. For example,  en or ja.  It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty. 
dateLocaleCountry - The locale country for input dateFormat string. For example, US or JP.  It will be ignored if dateFormat is empty or dateLocaleLang is empty. 
outFormat - The format of the output date/time. If it is empty, the output date/time will be in the format of date/time of OO Cental Server's, which is dependant on the Java locale.
outLocaleLang - The locale language for output string. For example,  en or ja. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty. 
outLocaleCountry - The locale country for output string. For example, US or JP. It will be ignored if outFormat is empty or outLocaleLang is empty.

Responses\:
success - The date was converted.
failure - The date could not be converted.

Result\:
The date in the new format.
The date in the new format.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.54aa20a6-98bc-436a-ab39-c6c89f8ae25a.description=This operation runs a SQL command. Inputs\: DBServerName - The hostname or ip address of the database server. DbType - The type of database to connect to. Valid values\: Oracle, MSSQL, Sybase, Netcool, DB2 and Custom. Default value\: Oracle Username - The username to use when connecting to the database. Password - The password to use when connecting to the database. instance - The name instance (for MSSQL Server). Leave it blank for default instance. DbPort - The port to connect to. Default values\: Oracle\: 1521, MSSQL\: 1433, Sybase\: 5000, Netcool\: 4100, DB2\: 50000. Database - The name of the database. authenticationType - The type of authentication used to access the database (applicable only to MSSQL type). Valid values\: sql, windows (for MSSQL) Default value\: sql dbClass - The classname of the JDBC driver to use. dbURL - The url required to load up the driver and make your connection. Command - The command to execute. timeout - Seconds to wait before timing out the SQL command execution. When the default value is used, there is no limit on the amount of time allowed for a running command to complete. Default value\: 0 databasePoolingProperties - Properties for database pooling configuration. This parameter replaces the databasePooling.properties file from 9x version (you may copy-paste the file content here). Pooling is disabled by default. For more details check the /Library/Operations/Database/JDBC folder description. Example\: db.pooling.enable\=true resultSetType - the result set type. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY, TYPE_SCROLL_INSENSITIVE,TYPE_SCROLL_SENSITIVE. Default value\: TYPE_FORWARD_ONLY resultSetConcurrency - the result set concurrency. See JDBC folder description for more details. Valid values\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY, CONCUR_UPDATABLE Default value\: CONCUR_READ_ONLY Results\: returnResult - This is the primary output. It contains the "Command completed successfully" message if the operation succeeded, or a failure message otherwise. outputText - The return result of SQL command. updateCount - The update count of the command executed. Responses\: success - The command was executed successfully. failure - Failed to execute the command. Note\: 1. Check the JDBC folder description for details on how to load database connectors. 2. In case of using subprograms like (GET_LINE, GET_LINES, NEW_LINE, PUT, PUT_LUNE) from DBMS_OUTPUT package, the DBMS_OUTPUT.ENABLE() declaration should be used before of these calls. 051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.5701cf56-5853-4ed5-a13a-d9c4e14e6d82.description=
This is an operation that does nothing. It can be used for filtering flow variables by feeding them in as inputs and filtering them on the results tab.

Inputs\:
field1 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field2 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field3 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.
field4 - optional input that can be used for filtering flow variables.

Responses\:
success - this operation never fails.

Compares two strings, returning a true response if and only if they contain the same sequence of characters. A null string is considered to be equal to an empty string.

Inputs\:
    string1 - The first string. 
Default value\: "" (empty)
    string2 - The second string.
Default value\: "" (empty)
    ignoreCase - If set to 'true', then the comparison ignores case considerations. The two strings are considered equal ignoring case if they are of the same length and corresponding characters in the two strings are equal ignoring case. If set to any value other than 'true', then the strings must match exactly to be considered equal.

Responses\:
    true - If the two strings are equal.
    false - If the two strings are not equal.
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.6651f228-628e-41eb-86a1-65ef581a7c4f.description=
Adds flow variables into the local context (available to itself and child flows only)

Input Parameters\:
keyNames - the names of the flow variables to use
myValues - the values to assign the flow variables
delimiter - a delimiter separating values and keys.

Responses\:
success - assigned the flow variable

Scriptlet Example\:
[$scriptletContext putGlobal\: $keyName, $myValue];

This operation makes a timed loop based on how many seconds user specifies in the input runLenghth. If want to let the operation set the timeStarted based on the time when the operation starts, leave the input timeStarted blank. After it is done, user can retrieve the timeStarted value.

Inputs\:
runLength - The number of seconds that this timer should loop for.
timeStarted - The time that the operation was started. This time is automatically put into the timeStarted variable in global context after the first run, and should be left blank before the first run.

Responses\:
continue - The timer loop is still running, do another operation in the loop.
done - The specified time has elapsed.

Compares two dates. If the locale is not specified, the inputs must be in the format of date/time format of OO Central Server's, which is dependant of Java Locale. You can use flow " Get Current Date and Time" to check upon the default date/time format. If locale is specified, the inputs must be in the format of the locale. If locale is not specified, then default locale will be used.

Inputs\:
d1 - The first date. For example, if locale is not specified and the OS default locale is English, the format could be "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM" or "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM PST". If locale en is specified, the format should be "July 12, 2006 4\:23\:20 PM PST".
d2 - The second date.  It must be in the format that is the same as d1.
threshold -The number of milliseconds around each date that still allows the dates to be considered equal.
localeLang - The locale language for date and time string. For example,  en or ja.
localeCountry - The locale country for date and time string. For example, US or JP. If localeLang is not specified, this input will be ingored.

Responses\:
before - If d1 is before d2.
equal - If d1 is < d2 + threshold and d1 > d2-threshold.
after - If d1 is after d2.
failure - Something went wrong.

Returns\:
The value of d1-d2 in milliseconds.

051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.d826e22e-db57-4e4c-8269-f897b8f07288.description=
This operation sends email via SMTP.      

Inputs\:
SMTPServer - The hostname or ip address of the smtp server.
MailType - The format of the message body. Valid values are\: html, text.
Attachments - A comma separated list of files to attach to the mail (Example\: c\:\test.txt,c\:\excel.xls).
From - SMTP address of the sender (Example\: sender@domain.com).
To - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of whom the email should be sent to (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com).
Cc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Bcc - A comma separated list of SMTP addresses of those whom should receive a blind carbon copy of this message. (Example\: receiver@domain.com, user@domain.com)
Subject - The subject of the message.
Body - The body of the message.
username - If SMTP authentication is needed, the username to send (Example\: username).
password - The password to use.
port - The port smtp service is listening on.
characterSet - The character set encoding for the entire email which includes subject, body, attached file name and the attached file. The values can be UTF-8, Shift_JIS, EUC-JP or ISO-2022-JP. Default value is UTF-8. 
contentTransferEncoding - Content transfer encoding scheme for the attachment. Supported encoding schemes are base64, quoted-printable and 7bit. Default value is quoted-printable. 7bit is supported only by ISO-2022-JP character set encoding. The operation will fail if 7bit is used with any other character set encoding.

Responses\:
success - Successfully sent the message.
failure - Failed to send message. See returnResult for more information.

Note\:
If SMTP authentication is not needed, then the operation will succeed even if invalid credentials are assigned to the username and password inputs.

051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.edcb1c76-8ef1-4368-8f3f-fa61dde8ec5a.description=
Runs the Ping command locally. 

Input Parameters\:
    targetHost - The target host to ping
    packetSize - The size of the ping packet
    packetCount - The number of packets to send. 
    timeout - The timeout in miliseconds for the Local Ping operation. Default is 90000.
    ipVersion - IP version forced to the ping command executed on the target host. For Windows -4 or -6 parameters will be added.On Linux will be used ping or ping6. For Solaris -A inet or -A inet6 parameters will be added. For empty string the operation will decide what format to use if targetHost is an ip literal; if targetHost is given as a hostname default 'ping' command will be used on each operating system.
Values\: 4, 6, '' (empty string without quotes).
Default\: '' (empty string without quotes).

Responses\:
    success - The command was executed successfully
    failure - The command could not be executed

Returns\:
    packetsSent - The number of packets sent
    packetsReceived - The number of packets received
    percentagePacketsLost - The percentage of packets lost
    transmissionTimeMin - The minimum time taken for transmitting the packet
    transmissionTimeMax - The maximum time taken for transmitting the packet
    transmissionTimeAvg - The average time taken for transmitting the packet
    returnResult - The raw output of the command
    returnCode - The return code from the executed command
    error - the STDERR of the command
051393f6-6cde-4f9a-91d5-82ae6762d5b5.f9b60967-1cbf-447f-a1a3-57eea78c8706.description=
Writes the data from "contents" input to the requested file. The operation can be used to overwrite existing content of the file,  append extra lines to it or even create a new file.

Input Parameters\:
file                - Full path to file (can be a UNC path, will attempt to create directory structure). If the file does not exist it is created first.
contents        - The contents to write to the file. Contents can have a new line delimiter which is also given as input to the operation, but it is optional. Example\: "This is line no. 01\nThis is line no. 2\n" where \n is the delimiter.
user              - Username to use for thread impersonation on the RAS host for this operation.
password      - Password for the user.
delimiter       - Specifies the newline delimiter (\n, \r\n, etc) that is used for the "contents" input.
overwrite      - Specifies whether to overwrite the file or append to it. By default, the used value is true. Accepted values\: true, false or the empty string. If this is left empty, the file will be overwritten.
characterSet - The character encoding used to write to the file. The default is UTF-8. Example values\: windows-1252, UTF-16, UTF-16BE,  ISO-8859-1, US-ASCII, Shift_JIS etc.

Responses\:
success - The contents were written to the file.
failure - The operation did not succeed in writing the contents to file.
